abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Education Sector Support
            Project for Kenya were as follows: outcomes were
            unsatisfactory; risk to development outcome was high; Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory; and borrower
            performance was unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned
            includes: developing systems requires taking informed risks.
            At the start, there did not appear to be significant threats
            to the development outcomes, from the perspective of policy
            or strategy. In order to ensure value for money and control
            corruption risks the focus needs to be on strengthening
            Government systems, and particularly on risk based
            approaches in financial management, procurement and auditing
            systems. Sector-Wide Approach (SWAps) must include a strong
            focus on governance and accountability. This can be achieved
            by including measures relating to social accountability,
            transparency, societal participation and a well-functioning
            whistle-blowing policy and procedures, particularly to
            ensure sufficient financing for them during implementation.
            Greater reliance should be given to civil society
            organizations in monitoring progress in the sector and in
            implementing accountability measures. The appraisal of
            country sector plans should be strengthened to ensure the
            inclusion of appropriate results measurement indicators and
            to set realistic targets. Bank projects supporting SWAps
            could then use the same indicators and targets to measure
            project results. Credible, robust and independent
            information and data should guide the design,
            implementation, and financing of a SWAp. Putting in place a
            series of impact evaluations during Program implementing can
            help to progressively develop informed policy decisions
            about scaling up specific interventions as was done in the
            case of the program. It is important to match up the program
            structure with the budget structure and to be able to
            monitor total expenditures on priority programs. Finally,
            working in a sector-wide approach that aims to utilize
            country systems requires strong, sustained and effective
            collaboration across the World Bank country team.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Education Sector
            Support Project is to support the Kenyan Government's
            program to provide basic education and improve the quality
            of education for all children by 2010. The Program consists
            of 23 investment programs, grouped into four areas of
            improvement. 1) Ensuring equity of access to basic
            education, includes: primary school infrastructure;
            non-formal schools; special needs education; adult basic
            education; expanding education opportunities in arid and
            semi-arid lands; gender and education investment program.
            2) Enhancing quality and learning achievement, includes:
            early childhood and development; school health, nutrition
            and feeding; primary school instructional materials;
            pre-service teacher education; in-service teacher education;
            quality assurance and standards; in-service training of
            teachers at secondary in math and science; information and
            communication technology in education.  3) Providing
            opportunities for further education and training, includes:
            guidance and counseling; secondary education; technical,
            industrial, vocational and entrepreneurship training
            (TIVET); and university education. 4) Strengthening
            education sector management, includes: HIV/AIDS; capacity
            building; education management information system; teacher
            management; monitoring and evaluation; information
            dissemination; and accountability with a specific focus on
            secondary and post secondary sectors. All of the investment
            programs emphasize information dissemination, transparency,
            accountability and addressing corruption, within the context
            of the sector's strategy for good governance, and with
            an increasing focus on secondary and post-secondary sectors.

repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Education Sector Support Program
            Project : resettlement policy framework

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the resettlement policy
            framework is to identify the principles and procedures to be
            followed in order to compensate people who may be negatively
            affected by the project so as to ensure they will be
            assisted to improve, or at least restore their living
            standards, income, and/or production capacity levels to
            pre-project levels. The general principles for the framework
            include : minimizing resettlement and land acquisition where
            possible; compensating, relocating, and rehabilitating
            project affected persons (PAPs); compensating all PAPs for
            their losses and/or income rehabilitation without regard to
            their legal rights; setting compensation at full replacement
            cost for houses and other structures, agricultural land of
            equal productive capacity, replacement of residential land
            at least of equal size, full compensation for crops, trees,
            and other similar agricultural products at market value;
            providing transportation assistance and home
            reestablishment, a dislocation allowance, along with
            providing residential land and replacement cost of homes;
            replacing land-for-land as the preferred option, or
            substituting cash ; minimizing the resettlement transition
            period; maintaining or improving the previous level of
            community services and access to resources; and arranging
            effective and timely internal and external monitoring of the
            implementation of resettlement measures.

repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Education Sector Support Program
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Education Sector Support Program is to assist the Government
            in the implementation of the Kenya Education Sector
            Strategic Plan (KESSP), and, as part of the process for
            attaining the KESSP goals, the project seeks to raise the
            net primary enrollment rate to at least 85 percent for boys
            and girls, and to raise the net primary enrollment rate in
            the North-Eastern Province to 25 percent; to raise the
            primary completion rate to 65 percent; to increase the
            number of secondary school places by 5 percent; to improve
            the education spending efficiency, as well as increase
            opportunities at the basic level; and, to establish an
            agreed policy framework for the Technical, Industrial,
            Vocational and Entrepreneurship Training (TIVET) and higher
            education sub-sectors. It is foreseen however, that the
            construction of schools and facilities, will pose adverse
            environmental effects, thus this environmental assessment
            presents mitigation measures as follows. Minimum design
            standards will be ensured, to include latrines, boarding
            accommodations, and school fencing and other security
            measures. Construction contractors shall comply with
            standards, as per precautionary clauses included in the
            technical specifications. Integrated water resources
            management should be promoted, to include as well rainwater
            harvesting. Capacity building should particularly target the
            needs of communities to mainstream their specific needs, in
            particular, those of underperforming students, orphans, and
            vulnerable children, or those affected by HIV/AIDS, and
            vulnerable groups. Likewise, capacity building shall focus
            on: obtaining land titles as needed; community mobilization;
            fundraising; liaisons with nongovernmental organizations and
            the private sector. Public awareness and sensitization
            campaigns should be promoted to inform communities,
            particularly in arid and semi-arid lands highlighting
            pastoral issues and needs. Participatory approaches should
            be built-in to involve stakeholders, as part of the
            field-based monitoring process to be implemented. Adequate
            water supply should be installed to provide hygienic
            standards in schools. Water quality should be regularly
            monitored, and water purification programmes should be
            initiated as required.

            education sub-sectors. It is foreseen however, that the
            construction of schools and facilities, will pose adverse
            environmental effects, thus this environmental assessment
            presents mitigation measures as follows. Minimum design
            standards will be ensured, to include latrines, boarding
            accommodations, and school fencing and other security
            measures. Construction contractors shall comply with
            standards, as per precautionary clauses included in the
            technical specifications. Integrated water resources
            management should be promoted, to include as well rainwater
            harvesting. Capacity building should particularly target the
            needs of communities to mainstream their specific needs, in
            particular, those of underperforming students, orphans, and
            vulnerable children, or those affected by HIV/AIDS, and
            vulnerable groups. Likewise, capacity building shall focus
            on: obtaining land titles as needed; community mobilization;
            fundraising; liaisons with nongovernmental organizations and
            the private sector. Public awareness and sensitization
            campaigns should be promoted to inform communities,
            particularly in arid and semi-arid lands highlighting
            pastoral issues and needs. Participatory approaches should
            be built-in to involve stakeholders, as part of the
            field-based monitoring process to be implemented. Adequate
            water supply should be installed to provide hygienic
            standards in schools. Water quality should be regularly
            monitored, and water purification programmes should be
            initiated as required.
